ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not only did I gain a good foundational knowledge about film camera usage, history, and developing techniques, but this class really helped me expand and refine the way I look at the world and approach image making. Lisa is an amazing teacher.

I gained a greater appreciation for creating meaningful black and white photographs and a deeper understanding for how to talk about photographs in a critical environment. Through regular discussions, lectures, and readings, I learned about important photographers, styles, and ways of looking at the world that all helped me hone my artistic voice.
basic black and white photography skills (how to use a film camera, how to develop / print)

I learned so much about the way photography works, mechanically, chemically, and artistically. I had the chance to develop a deeper relationship with my camera, with film, with the dark room, with my own eyes, and with the visual world around mes
I learned the fundamentals of artistic photography.
I learned the fundamentals of shooting with a 35mm film camera and printing in the darkroom. Also learned a bit of B&W photo history and got to visit a couple of exhibitions with the class.
Developing and printing B&W film. Thinking visually, talking about images, getting to know other people's work and style.

This class is a must take if you're interested in photography and want to learn the craft of black & white film photo. It will make you look at the world differently and develop a photographer's eye. You'll walk around and start composing and wanting to take pictures even if you don't have your camera on you. You'll learn the fundamentals of exposure, which will translate well to digital photo and video.
Ability to work independently in the dark room. Intellectual approach to photography.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: interesting class, good balance of work for other classes, lifelong skills, variety of lectures from Lisa and guest lectures from the graduate school; I learned quite a bit about different photographer's perspectives and what makes a meaningful photograph, which has continued to influence how and what I shoot. I found getting that kind of exposure to other artists incredibly valuable! I think the course would have been even better if there were more group discussion after these lectures. The beginning of the course was more lecture heavy from Lisa, which was more conducive to discussions because we were all in the classroom. Those were valuable for me. Towards the end, it seemed like there was more of an emphasis on listening (but not fully processing these guest artists) and getting into the darkroom to make photographs, which is important, but many of us were doing that outside of class time. I think the class may have benefited from more group discussions about the guest artists and students' own work before critiques, so maybe one or two more classes devoted to discussion or lecture rather than the darkroom?

the course provides a solid technical introduction to photographyi am now able to shoot, develop, and print on my own, and understand the basics of the craft. i also have basic knowledge of the history of black and white photography. 

because the course assignments heavily center street photography, i think a conversation about the ethics and practice of street photography should happen much earlier in the semester to ensure that students navigate new haven with respect and thoughtfulness.
This is is a great class and Lisa is a fantastic professor. Its hard to balance hands on time with theoretical discussions, and we tended to do more of the former which I was glad for.
Wonderfully taught. Could use more discussion of formal technique.

Lisa is such a gem. She is extremely kind and approachable, not to mention super supportive and helpful to all of her students. Our class got along well, and I had a lot of fun getting to know everyone in the darkroom. The class is well organized and structured, and Lisa is great at communicating with her students about what the weekly assignments were. There really was no weakness. If I could change one thing, it would be to add more time between the pre-Thanksgiving critique and the final critique. I felt like there wasn't enough time after Thanksgiving break to print out my pictures for the final.

The class was structured well in that we were given weekly assignments, though whether we had to actually comply in printing these particular photos for critique was up to us. It would have been nice to start developing and printing earlier in the semester and learning fundamental techniques like dodging and burning earlier, though some difficulties with the darkroom slowed us down at the beginning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! One of the best classes I have taken at Yale. The type of work (shooting, developing, printing), and getting exposure to such an inspirational range of guest (and student) photographers was a truly unique experience, and something that will inform my artistic perspective for the rest of my life. There is an impressive arts community at Yale and this intro class gave me a glimpse into what is happening in it.
yes, if you are looking to learn the basics of black and white photography
Yes. Absolutely. Anyone who has any interest in photography should take this class.
Yes, it is excellent. Should be a universal requirement.
Highly recommend!!!! If you're down to do the work, then take it. I had so much fun and learned a lot. It was incredibly rewarding.
YESYESYES. Lisa and Dylan were great. It was one of my fav courses I've taken at Yale so far.

Absolutely! This class will make you think and learn in ways that most other classes will not. You'll be working with your hands and physically exerting yourself, but in my opinion it allows you to access a place of catharsis in the darkroom.
Yes! Lisa is amazing and I loved working on the dark room. Great way to connect other topics of study to a creative practice.
